This theory explains the behavior of ideal gases based on a set of postulates:

  • Gases consist of tiny particles in constant, random, straight-line motion.
  • The volume of the gas particles themselves is negligible compared to the container volume.
  • There are no attractive or repulsive forces between gas particles.
  • Collisions between particles and with container walls are perfectly elastic (no energy is lost).
  • The average kinetic energy of the particles is directly proportional to the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
` }, { title: "Molecular Velocities", content: `

Not all gas molecules move at the same speed. Their speeds are described by a distribution:

  • Most Probable Velocity ($$u_{mp}$$): The speed possessed by the maximum number of molecules.
  • Average Velocity ($$u_{avg}$$): The arithmetic mean of the speeds of all molecules.
  • Root Mean Square (RMS) Velocity ($$u_{rms}$$): The square root of the mean of the squares of the speeds. It is used to calculate kinetic energy.

For any gas, the relationship is: $$u_{rms} > u_{avg} > u_{mp}$$

` }, { title: "Real Gases & Deviation from Ideal Behavior", content: `

Real gases deviate from ideal behavior because the postulates of the Kinetic Molecular Theory are not perfectly true:

  1. Real gas molecules do have finite volume.
  2. There are intermolecular attractive forces between real gas molecules.

Deviations are most significant at high pressure and low temperature.

The Van der Waals Equation

This is a modified ideal gas equation that accounts for the behavior of real gases:

$$ \\left(P + \\frac{an^2}{V^2}\\right)(V - nb) = nRT $$
  • The 'a' term corrects for intermolecular forces (the pressure correction).
  • The 'b' term corrects for the volume of gas molecules (the volume correction).
